Award.AwardTitle: DDRIG: High Latitude Adaptations and Geoarchaeology at the Little John site, Yukon Territory, Canada
Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports a dissertation project to conduct excavation, sampling and lithic, geoarchaeological, chronological, and paleoenvironmental analysis of materials from the Little John site in Yukon, Canada. The site is important as a stratified, Late Pleistocene-Early Holocene site with archaeological assemblages relating to the so-called Nenana/Chindadn (without microblades) and Denali (microblades) complexes. The site includes a locus with stratigraphic separation of paleosols and holds promise for evaluating the proposition that these two complexes are culturally distinct (presumably implying unrelated populations) and/or functionally distinct (i.e., relating to technological evolution or seasonal tool kit changes) as has been argued variously from other sites in central Alaska. The co-PI (Ph.D. student) will help supervise the excavation and lead the analyses to evaluate whether the assemblage types are stratigraphically and chronologically distinct and whether they correlate with paleoenvironmental change. These correlations presumably will yield insights to help clarify the long-standing debate about the significance of these assemblages in the archaeology of Eastern Beringia.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under the supervision of Dr. E. James Dixon, Mr. Michael Grooms (Co-PI) has completed his dissertation research that focuses on technological change during the late Pleistocene-early Holocene transition in eastern Beringia. The Co-PI applied chronological and geological methods to address the complex chronological relationship between archaeological components at the Little John site, Yukon Territory. Regionally, in Beringia, this problem is expressed with the dichotomy of the Chindadn/Nenana (non-microblade) and Denali (microblade) complexes. Specifically, the Co-PI analyzed the artifact-bearing stratigraphy at the site to determine if past environment or climate (deglaciation, Younger Dryas) changes, which manifest in the form of changes in soils and sediments, are contemporaneous with technological changes after the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM), (specifically the period between 15,000 - 8,000 cal BP).

The Little John site (KdVo-6), the case study for this project, is important to this discussion because it represents the easternmost expression of both Chindadn/Nenana and Denali artifacts in a unique stratified context. The site contains loess/paleosol stratigraphic sequences and a substantive faunal assemblage spanning the past 15,000 years. This research has enabled a reliable correlation of technological strategies, such as stone-tool technology, to specific environmental changes during climate perturbations at the site. This research accurately defined the association of the artifacts, fauna, and climate proxies that aid in the understanding of late Pleistocene human adaptive strategies within specific environments and at certain times.

The intellectual merits of this proposal include enhancing current knowledge of human adaptations to high latitude environments. This project has increased the knowledge of the timing of human occupations at the Little John site by submitting ten radiocarbon (AMS 14C) dates and 5 stimulated luminescence (IRSL) dates for specific and targeted stratigraphic contexts. Clusters of artifacts and animal bones within a discrete horizontal plane and geologic context identify these discrete human occupations. The addition of these dates within the existing site chronology has helped to further refine the chronology at the site. Combined with geological analysis, the dates firmly place human occupations before and during the several warming and cooling events during the Last Glacial Maximum (B?lling-Aller?d, Younger Dryas). The multiple human occupations also reveal a range of stone-tool technologies during this time period that also associates with broader, regional technological changes seen in Central Alaska. The relationship of the stone-tool technologies to climate perturbations was analyzed with sediment analysis that included sediment description, elemental identification, mineralogical identification, and micromorphology. These sediment attributes have provided information on pre- and post-depositional processes associated with the surrounding environment and climate changes. 

The broader impacts of the research have aided in the training and education of the Co-PI in interdisciplinary and community-based collaborative approaches to anthropological research. The collaborative focus of the fieldwork with the White River First Nation and Yukon College has advanced the Co-PI?s research as a well-rounded anthropological perspective that includes indigenous perspectives. The project required the consent and participation of underrepresented groups of Canadian First Nations at Beaver Creek (Yukon) and Alaskan tribal groups at Northway. These relationships were crucial to furthering scientific education with the groups by participating in on-site interpretation. This project has developed and strengthened partnerships between the University of New Mexico (UNM), the University of New Mexico Earth and Planetary Sciences Department, Yukon College Anthropology and Geological Technology, Yukon Cultural Heritage Branch, Yukon Geological Survey, Archaeometry Laboratory at the University of Missouri Research Reactor, Utah State University, A. E. Lalonde AMS Laboratory at the University of Ottawa, University of Alaska, Tanana Chiefs Conference, and tribal and First Nations groups of the US/Canadian Yukon-Alaskan borderlands. Dissemination of results has included participation in presentations at local, national, and international conferences. Dissemination will continue with the completion of the Co-PI?s dissertation and contributions at the on-site Little John visitor center, the Yukon College and UNM site webpages, and to local Alaskan and Canadian Native and non-Native community groups and organizations.
